title: Research Associate in Optical Trapping of Nanoparticles in Optofluidic Waveguides (Fixed Term)
text:
★ View Employer Profile 
Fixed-term: The funds for this post are available for 2 years in the first instance. 
Applications are invited for an experimental Postdoctoral Research Associate in the new group of Dr Tijmen Euser in the NanoPhotonics Centre in the Department of Physics, University of Cambridge. 
Working in several collaborative teams across different departments, across the UK, and internationally, you will be studying advanced light-matter interactions in novel optofluidic waveguides. Building on our recent work on optical manipulation in hollow-core photonic crystal fibre, this project focuses on nanoscale waveguides and particles. The aim is to provide a deeper understanding of the interplay of optical forces, fluidic flow, and heat-transport in these systems, and to transfer this knowledge to advanced applications. In related experiments, you will develop novel optofluidic reactor concepts that will have a major impact on the studies of photo-catalytic systems and novel light-activatable anticancer drugs. 
Candidates will hold a strong physics or related PhD or be close to obtaining a PhD, with experience in optical trapping, spatial light modulation/holographic beam shaping, or nanoparticle spectroscopy. 
In addition to proven experimental skills the candidate should ideally have experience in working across disciplinary boundaries. They should expect to be involved in both construction of new optical trapping- and spectroscopy rigs using lasers as well as a variety of chemical sample preparations. Experience in the field of photonic crystal fibre or fibre optics in general would be helpful, as well as with microfluidic technology. 
The Cambridge NanoPhotonics Centre ( http://www.np.phy.cam.ac.uk ), consisting of the groups of Prof Jeremy Baumberg and Dr Tijmen Euser, collaborates widely across the University of Cambridge including the Departments of Chemistry, Engineering, Physics of Medicine, Cancer Research UK, Chemical Engineering, Materials as well as many international partners, industry, and with several major EU programmes. The group of Dr Euser brings in strong expertise in waveguide-based optical trapping and photochemistry and synergies with a wide variety of researchers across the University of Cambridge. A description of recent research and publications can be seen on our website ( http://www.np.phy.cam.ac.uk/research-themes/optofluidics ). 
To apply online for this vacancy and to view further information about the role, please visit: 
http://www.jobs.cam.ac.uk/job/8323 . This will take you to the role on the University’s Job Opportunities pages. There you will need to click on the 'Apply online' button and register an account with the University's Web Recruitment System (if you have not already) and log in before completing the online application form. 
Please ensure that you upload your Curriculum Vitae (CV), your list of Research publications, and a covering letter in the Upload section of the online application. If you have any questions about the application process, please contact Mrs Angela Campbell ( ajc267@cam.ac.uk ). 
Please quote reference KA07280 on your application and in any correspondence about this vacancy. 
The University values diversity and is committed to equality of opportunity.
